column3: >yeah, this looks like something I made. will have to listen to this at some point.
>adding a @logs virtual group to this zet, because it makes exporting an easier problem to solve.
>this way, I don't have to do tree traversal and shit like that. just make sure messages are tied to this group.

>there's no way to check if a entry belongs to exactly *one* of the core groups being exported. so it's very possible to create duplicate entries by mistake. we will cross that bridge when we get there. #updates
>success! first wavetable loaded from a crate into an instance of =oscf= via =monolith=. woo!
>lots of duplicates removed. I have to be more careful about which groups I link messages too!
>zet message generation for weewiki is up and running now. testing out !logs and !akwf.
>added some shell scripts in a folder called 'u'. should save a few keystrokes this way.
>today, I'm implementing a shuffle feature in the zet that allows me to randomly pick files given a pattern. the hope is to better automate guess-and-check.
>some fruitful results using phase distortion today on an !akwf waveform. It'll be interesting to see what sort of timbral variety that technique will bring.
>applying a @labels group. will make up categories as I go.
>some more utilties managing labels and groups. I now can look up an entry and get the list of groups and labels they are a part of.
>imported some drum samples I cut from unfa beatboxing.
>the bc label is meant to be for things related to my breathing cards etude series.
>off to make another fragment using 3 random !akwf wavetables
>some mildly better presentation when display logs. abbreviated UUIDs are visible, and references are avaiable as well. at 60k rows, the query lag is noticeable, but tolerable.
>working on some abstractions for #monolith that will make it easier to test out waveforms. trying to make this a daily ritual for a while.
>putting the tcross node in monolith to good use. it's made for wavetables. since it takes in a phasor, I can also apply phase distortion techniques to it as well.
>a new wavetable study in #frags. this would be wt4.
>linked here are the 3 random waveforms attempted to be used. the goal is to build something pitched and controlled via a trigger.
>built tabmorf today. testing it out on some random !waveedit waveforms today.

>I just made a TODO app today that was a bunch of weewiki commands wrapped in one shell script. It's tempting to do the same here. It would make this system re-usable incase I wanted to start another one of these up again.
>at some point, I will be extracting and documenting AAS sample packs here. Why they couldn't just supply the WAV files instead of their shit JSON format is beyond me.
>I feel like it's been a while since I last did anything here. been a busy week. no time for fun and games. maybe tomorrow?
>I really need to make a README for how to use this system. It hasn't even been that long and I'm forgetting the conventions.
>working on a usage page so I don't forget how to use this.
>with this wt6 exercise, I'm discovering that primitive waveshapes like triangles, squares, and sawtooths, need to be compared against themselves. Otherwise they sound bland and generic.
>yup, big performance improvement disabling !aw_2020_wav32. working off partial segments of the database seems like a design consideration moving forward.
>disabled the references in the feed pages and re-enabled !aw_2010_wav32. it was not worth the CPU cycles.
>also, introducing !sh1wf. Found on lines the other day.
>just imported !kawaiwf, single cycle loops from the Kawai K1.

>wow, it has been months since I touched this. I'm swinging back into wavetables, thanks to Gest, my gesture synthesizer. That will enable me to dynamically morph between an arbitrary number of waveforms in arbitrary order. Really should set me forward.
>added drums yesterday. still getting used to this system. it's all about habbits.
>thinking I might turn my utilitie scripts into a shell script, similar to !zetdo.

>on second thought, are the scripts really that bad? I mean it's not like the shell script could be used outside of the directory. plus, this makes it more decentralized. will push onwards with what I have so far.

>added rpicker. good design pattern to look at moving forward. really solidifies how self-contained scripts are going to be better than a monolithic CLI. Hopefully many more custom SQLite queries in the future.
>adding a play shortcut that would resolve files and then play them in mplayer was a good idea. all I need to do is mount the sqlar via sqlarfs.
>the u/hist utility provides a very nice view of recently logged samples tied to a group. will probably turn it into an HTML view at some point.
